data.title: James Walter Mansfield; Sophia Mansfield; Walter Thomas Mansfield – Mill Road Cemetery
data.text:
CFHS code – CL116a This inscribed flower holder was not recorded in the CFHS survey and was coded by FOMRC

Parish St Clements

Monument

A small stone cube with hole in the top for flowers and carved inscriptions on 4 sides. The inscriptions are now very eroded. It was found when mapping the parish of St Clements but we were not certain if it was in the correct location. It stands within the kerbstones of Elliot CL116, 2 rows from the east path.

There is no known relationship between the 2 families. There is a monument, marked out by barley twist kerbs but no obvious inscription, directly behind the Elliot kerbstones

Inscription

Sophia Mansfield died October 10th 1929 aged 67

James W Mansfield died Feb 16th 1932 aged 74

Walter T Mansfield died Sept 13 1853 aged 68

Rest in Peace

James Walter was recorded as having been buried in this parish in 1932 but not Sophia in 1929 – this may be due to missing pages in the burial register.

Sophia Mansfield née Willmott (1863 – 1929) In various records Sophy, and Sophie were used.

An 8 year old Sophia Willmott was living in Orwell in 1871 with her parents Joseph and Naomi and 7 siblings. Joseph was a labourer. In 1880 a Sophy Willmott had a baby that was baptised Alma Willmott and no father was named. In the 1881 census baby Alma was living with her grandparents Joseph and Naomi and Sophia was living and working as a kitchen maid at the Wrestlers Arms in Petty Cury, Cambridge. Alma died in Orwell in May 1881 aged 8 months there was an inquest where it was stated that she died of acute bronchitis and confirmed that she was the illegitimate daughter of Sophie (sic) Willmott. Her full name was given here as Alma Souter Willmott.

We have not found a marriage for Sophia but she and James had at least 10 children Henry (1883), Walter Thomas (1885/6), Alma (1888), Henry Walter Thomas (1889), Letitia (1890), Horace (1891), Herbert (1893-19), Arthur (1896 -1897), Kate (1900) and Ethel Lily (1903 – 1905)

Herbert was killed in WW1 and was buried in France. In 1911 aged 17 he had been working as a grocer’s errand boy.

When Alma was born they were living in 3 Quince’s Court, Hobson St

In 1891 they were living in Turnsell Court, Hobson St.

In 1911 they were in Ram Yard

1921 they occupied Dove House New Park St along with their son Arthur, daughter Kate and Alma & William Gillingham (daughter & Son in law).

In 1921 Sophia was working as a charlady for Taylor a solicitor.

James Walter Mansfield (25th February 1857 – 1932)

Walter was born in Great Wilbraham his given name was James Walter but on most documents he was recorded as Walter. He was the son of David and Mary Ann (née Childs) Walter became a cabdriver

From the Cambridge Daily News Jan & Feb 1982 and Mike Petty CDN1989 we learnt more about James.

Mike Petty wrote an article in the news in 1989 where he states that ‘Lame Walter’ was the last of the cabdrivers in 1917. It seems that he was much loved by his customers as they helped him buy a new cab in 1912

A photo published in the CDN in January 1982 sparked a series of letters from his relations who remembered him fondly.

As he got older and arthritic he made himself an advertising box cycle which was hand operated – His dog Ruff, would sometimes help to pull him alongand sometimes his grandchildren would give him a push. When Walter died Ruff lay under the cart, pining, and died a year after his master.

Walter Thomas Mansfield (1886 – 1952/3)

Walter Thomas was the 3rd child if James and Sophia. In 1911 he was also working as a cab driver and by 1921 was working as a chauffeur for W Moss Cycle & Motor Engineer and lodging with the Horobin family at 1 Perowne St.

[If you have any further information about this family, please contact us at Friendsofmillroadcemetery@gmail.com]

By Mary Naylor

Sources

CFHS Transcripts of parish records

British Newspaper Archive on Line

Cambridgeshire Collection

Roll of Honour

Commonwealth War Graves Commission

The origins of the name Dove House can be found here (clicking the link will take you to a new window)

https://capturingcambridge.org/centre/portugal-street/dove-house-close/
